title: The Steward's Heart
devotional:
Old Man Hemlock, as the townsfolk called him, wasn't known for his generosity. His apple orchard, however, was legendary. It produced the juiciest, reddest apples anyone had ever tasted. Every autumn, people would line up, hoping to purchase a bushel, but Hemlock always sold them at exorbitant prices, hoarding the profits. He reasoned that he had worked hard for the orchard, and the fruits were his to do with as he pleased. He even let some apples rot on the ground, rather than giving them away.

One harsh winter, a blight struck the region. Many orchards were devastated, including Hemlock’s. He watched helplessly as his prized apple trees withered and died. His wealth diminished, and he began to feel the sting of loneliness. No one offered him assistance; his reputation had preceded him. Destitute and alone, he finally understood the error of his ways. His stewardship had been one of selfish gain, not of nurturing and sharing God's bounty.

The following spring, something remarkable happened. From the roots of a few surviving trees, small shoots began to emerge. Hemlock, humbled and desperate, tended to them with a newfound sense of purpose. He didn't expect to profit; he simply wanted to care for what little remained. He researched organic methods, using compost and natural pest controls. He learned about the interconnectedness of the soil, the trees, and the ecosystem. He shared his knowledge with the few people who would listen, teaching them how to nurture their own small gardens.

Years passed. Slowly, painstakingly, Hemlock rebuilt his orchard. This time, however, his approach was different. He offered apples to the community at affordable prices, sharing the harvest with the needy. He taught young people the art of grafting and pruning. His orchard became a place of learning, community, and generosity. Old Man Hemlock, once known for his stinginess, was now revered for his wisdom and kindness. He finally understood that true wealth lies not in hoarding, but in stewarding God's gifts for the benefit of all.

This story serves as a powerful reminder that we are all stewards of God's resources, whether they be material possessions, talents, or opportunities. Our responsibility is not merely to accumulate, but to use these gifts wisely and generously, for the glory of God and the good of others. True fulfillment comes not from what we possess, but from what we give away.
image_description: A close-up of healthy apple tree saplings sprouting from the ground in an orchard after a harsh winter.
insights: The concept of stewardship is central to Christian teaching. 1 Peter 4:10 states, 'Each of you should use whatever gift you have received to serve others, as faithful stewards of God’s grace in its various forms.' This verse emphasizes that all our abilities and possessions are gifts from God, entrusted to us for the purpose of serving others. Similarly, the parable of the talents in Matthew 25:14-30 highlights the importance of using our gifts wisely and productively, rather than burying them out of fear or selfishness.
prayer: Heavenly Father, forgive me for the times I have been a poor steward of Your gifts. Help me to recognize all that I have as coming from You, and empower me to use my resources, talents, and opportunities to serve others and glorify Your name. Grant me a generous heart and a willingness to share what I have with those in need. May I always remember that true wealth lies not in what I possess, but in how I steward Your blessings. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: In what areas of your life are you being called to be a better steward? What gifts or resources are you currently holding back from using for God's glory and the benefit of others? How can you cultivate a more generous and selfless attitude towards your possessions and abilities?
